comments.author: Straight_Turnip7056
comments.body:
The innovation of this city continues to wow me. I visit less than once a year, so can get more surprised with some changes, than locals who may be see a more gradual change.


This year, it was **using your bank card** to check-in/out in public transport. Heard that you can also do it for NS trains, although didn't try it. As far as I know, no major European country has this. And, this is an unimaginably great convenience for tourists. Not having to worry about zones/ day passes/ whatever, and paying as you go. **Kudos to GVB**! Really!

comments.author: Nariot
comments.body:
Looking for an old bar

Hey everyone, ive been having a discussion with an old friend about his time in amsterdam in the late 80s, and he mentioned an old and hidden bar/restaurant called Hotel Budapest. He says he used to take a taxi to the Penny Bar, walk down to the canal, and walk down a large set of stairs to the canal. The bar was apparently just there and had very few seats. The vibe was like being in someones home. The food was excellent and apparently the owner and staff were very good at remembering guests, even after years passed.

Just curious to see if I can find any more information about this place. Google searches havent yielded anything and I am not physically there, but i figured maybe someone knows someone who remembers the place. I want to find pictures and take my friend there for a trip down memory lane before he is too ill to travel, because this place held some of his fondest memories.

Thanks everyone!

comments.author: JamLikeCannedSpam
comments.body:
FYI "coffeeshop" in Amsterdam is a cannabis establishment.

Sounds like you're looking for a speciality coffee cafe. Dak is an incredible roaster and has a very modern tasting showroom (no food). Saint Jean also serves their beans and is a bakery with a modern feel, easier to get to as well. Sango is also right by the central station with interesting coffee choices, and is great to hang around a little while. I don't love their pastries though. Uncommon Cafe is a sit-down option as well for coffee tasting, pastries and food. I highly recommend their toasted banana bread dessert plate.

Friedhats and Rum Baba are amazing roasters, but I wouldn't say their cafes have a modern feel like Blue Bottle. You also can find Friedhats coffee at OSLO, which has pastries but no seating.

Also, since I notice you're from Austin... I'm jealous of your tacos right now. One of the things AMS unfortunately doesn't do well/cheap ðŸ˜­ But thankfully for you the coffee and pastries here are excellent.

comments.author: DashingDino
comments.body:
> How are we supposed to keep organic waste for 3-4 days?

You collect waste in a closable waste bin in your home for a few days, this is totally normal

> Since keeping smelly trash for 4 days is a long time, and I live very close to Zuid, is it allowed to use Zuidâ€™s underground bins?

There is no rule against bringing your trash to an underground bin, no

> It says that trash is collected between 6:00 and 7:30. Does that mean Iâ€™m supposed to put it out around 6 am?

Yes, they don't want you putting out the trash the night before because it gives time for rats and gulls to get to the bags and rip them apart, creating a huge mess that needs to be cleaned up and worsening the rat problem

> This question isnâ€™t about Restafval but about paper and glass bins.

Paper goes in the paper container, glass in the glass container, there are no exceptions for bags

comments.author: enirih24c
comments.body:
It's fine but fully for tourists. If you want a more traditional spot I'd go with Vleminckx (also in Centrum) or Pietersma on the Albert Cuyp market. Some other spots you can try for coffee are Coffee Bru, Wakuli, Hummingbird, 4850, Yusu, Five Ways, Uncommon and Skina. Uncommon has two shops right across from eachother, one is a bit more basic, the other focuses on ferments and artisanal pastries/food. 

Try and find a bar that serves ossenworst if you want to try local meat products or grab a sandwich from Slagerij Vet on Zeedijk (broodje ossenworst met peper or broodje halfom). If a bar has a mostly wood interior, lots of old deco on the wall and smells of stale beer it's usually solid (for a super central place visit In 't Aepjen and order a beer with a jenever shot, ossenworst and cheese).

If you want to avoid super touristy restaurants I'd check out the Oud-West and Oost areas, both are gentrified but also predominantly residential areas. For more hipstery restaurants check out the Noord district, stuff is a lot more scattered but overall good quality. For more central spots most places on Utrechtsestraat are good.

comments.author: dullestfranchise
comments.body:
>They can translate and make it available, if they want to earn their brokerage

No they can't. Brokers aren't allowed to write KIDs unless they are also the creator of the financial product.


The financial institution that manages the ETF has to make that document. So the question remains did Direxion make a Dutch KID for their ETF? If not then not a single Dutch broker is legally allowed to let their retail investors invest in it.

ABN AMRO can only make KID for their own financial investment products.

Read the link I posted in my first comment to you. The article explains the legal requirements.
